articles.headline: In Tight Race, Victor May Be Ohio Lawyers
articles.snippet: This precariously balanced state could be the place where the two parties begin filing the inevitable lawsuits over voting irregularities, experts say.
articles.abstract: This precariously balanced state could be the place where the two parties begin filing the inevitable lawsuits over voting irregularities, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio  If the outcome of next week’s presidential election is close, this precariously balanced state could be the place where the two parties begin filing the inevitable lawsuits over voting irregularities, experts say.

articles.headline: New Anxiety Grips Russia’s Economy
articles.snippet: Russia’s cash reserves have fallen to $484 billion, from a peak of just under $600 billion, putting the success of the economy in doubt.
articles.abstract: Russia’s cash reserves have fallen to $484 billion, from a peak of just under $600 billion, putting the success of the economy in doubt.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  At the start of the global financial crisis, Russian authorities insisted they had ample cash reserves to weather any storm. But as sorrow has succeeded sorrow  plummeting oil prices, a 70 percent descent in stock markets here, a global credit crisis and a slow-motion bank run on this country’s private banks  Russia has had to spend its reserves faster than anybody imagined.

articles.headline: Motown Is Bleak as Big Three Could Become Two
articles.snippet: The merger of General Motors and Chrysler is a cultural shift that some people in Detroit find hard to swallow.
articles.abstract: The merger of General Motors and Chrysler is a cultural shift that some people in Detroit find hard to swallow.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Fall in this city has always felt a bit like spring elsewhere. It is traditionally the season of fresh starts for the hometown industry, a time when the auto companies get a jump on the calendar and begin shipping next year’s models to dealers.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Growing Doubts on Palin Take a Toll, Poll Finds
articles.snippet: Though a focus on taxes is helping John McCain, Sarah Palin is weighing down the Republican ticket, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.abstract: Though a focus on taxes is helping John McCain, Sarah Palin is weighing down the Republican ticket, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.lead_paragraph: A growing number of voters have concluded that Senator John McCain’s running mate, Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska, is not qualified to be vice president, weighing down the Republican ticket in the last days of the campaign, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Dalia Sussman

articles.headline: Ford Says It Can Make It Without a Merger
articles.snippet: While rivals talk mergers, Ford executives vow to survive by staying independent and stepping up production.
articles.abstract: While rivals talk mergers, Ford executives vow to survive by staying independent and stepping up production.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich.  With United States vehicle sales down nearly 13 percent this year, most car companies have been cutting production rather than increasing it.

articles.headline: Fed Adds $21 Billion to Loans for A.I.G.
articles.snippet: The American International Group has access to $144 billion in credit from the Federal Reserve under three programs, but its cash needs could grow even further.
articles.abstract: The American International Group has access to $144 billion in credit from the Federal Reserve under three programs, but its cash needs could grow even further.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group said Thursday that it had been given access to the Federal Reserve’s new commercial paper program, allowing it to reduce its reliance on a costlier emergency loan from the Fed.

articles.headline: A Clever Move by Porsche on VW’s Stock
articles.snippet: Porsche may have pulled off a brilliant new-fashioned corner in Volkswagen stock, using derivatives in clever ways that no one had thought of before.
articles.abstract: Porsche may have pulled off a brilliant new-fashioned corner in Volkswagen stock, using derivatives in clever ways that no one had thought of before.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, a corner is not just an intersection of two streets. It is also a way to extract huge profits from speculators who had the temerity to sell a stock short.

articles.headline: Mortgage Plan May Irk Those It Doesn’t Help
articles.snippet: Experts say it is difficult to devise programs to aid distressed homeowners without giving everyone else a reason to mail the keys back to their lenders.
articles.abstract: Experts say it is difficult to devise programs to aid distressed homeowners without giving everyone else a reason to mail the keys back to their lenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Treasury Department prepares a $40 billion program to help delinquent homeowners avoid foreclosure, it confronts a difficult challenge: not making the plan too tempting to people like Todd Lawrence.

articles.headline: In Crisis, Prosecutors Put Aside Turf Wars
articles.snippet: The flood of investigations that sprang from the financial crisis has led to an increase in cooperation among state and federal prosecutors, especially in New York.
articles.abstract: The flood of investigations that sprang from the financial crisis has led to an increase in cooperation among state and federal prosecutors, especially in New York.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Sept. 25, as the world financial crisis escalated, two of New York’s most powerful lawyers met for lunch in a restaurant near Wall Street with a name that recalled happier times: Bull Run.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Weiser and Ben White

articles.headline: Somalia’s Pirates Flourish in a Lawless Nation
articles.snippet: The country is in chaos, but one line of work, piracy, seems to be benefiting quite openly from the desperation.
articles.abstract: The country is in chaos, but one line of work, piracy, seems to be benefiting quite openly from the desperation.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOOSAASO, Somalia  This may be one of the most dangerous towns in Somalia, a place where you can get kidnapped faster than you can wipe the sweat off your brow. But it is also one of the most prosperous.
